document_type: Remote Technical Standards - Use of Third Party Software

aim.aim_description: To make customers in peer-to-peer gambling aware that they may be gambling against a software program (designed to automatically participate in gambling within certain parameters, sometimes referred to as a bot), or a human aided by third party software

requirements.title: Information About Bots and Third Party Software
requirements.full_text: Where peer-to-peer customers may be gambling against programs deployed by other customers to play on their behalf, or customers assisted by third party software, information should be made available that describes that this is possible, and if it is against the operator's terms and conditions, how to report suspected use.

implementation_guidance.full_text: The warning and information about how to complain should be included in game descriptions, rules, terms and conditions, 'help', 'how to play' or other general product information pages. The warning should also inform customers that if they use a program to gamble on their behalf, other customers may be able to exploit it.
key_points: Where customers may be gambling against bots or software-assisted players, inform them
If against terms and conditions, explain how to report suspected use
Include warning in game descriptions, rules, terms, help pages
Warn that using bots may be exploitable by other customers
information_requirements: Describe that customers may be gambling against programs (bots) deployed by others
Describe that customers may be gambling against software-assisted humans
If against terms and conditions, explain how to report suspected use

additional_warning.content: If customers use a program to gamble on their behalf, other customers may be able to exploit it
additional_warning.purpose: Deter use of bots by highlighting vulnerability

requirements.citation: UK Gambling Commission - Remote Technical Standards, RTS Requirement 16A

requirements.title: Clarity on Permitted and Prohibited Software
requirements.full_text: Operators must make it clear to players whether the use of third party software is permitted and if so which types. Operators that prohibit certain types of third party software must implement measures intended to deter, prevent, and detect their use.

implementation_guidance.full_text: Clear, accessible information about the types of software that are permitted or prohibited should be included within terms and conditions and the players guide, as a minimum. This does not have to be an extensive list but could be a description of the key features of the software.
key_points: Must make clear whether third party software use is permitted
If prohibited, must implement measures to deter, prevent, and detect use
Include information in terms and conditions and players guide (minimum)
Can describe key features rather than extensive list

clarity_requirements.permitted_software: Make clear if permitted and which types

enforcement_measures.when_required: Operators that prohibit certain types of third party software

disclosure_requirements.content_format: Clear, accessible information about types of software permitted or prohibited
disclosure_requirements.detail_level: Does not require extensive list - can describe key features

requirements.citation: UK Gambling Commission - Remote Technical Standards, RTS Requirement 16B

requirements.title: Operator Disclosure of Own Bot Use
requirements.full_text: Where operators use programs to participate in gambling on their behalf in peer-to-peer gambling, easily accessible information must be displayed, which clearly informs customers that the operator uses this kind of software.

implementation_guidance.full_text: Peer-to-peer gambling operators that use software to gamble on their behalf (for example, poker robots) should display a notice to customers on the home pages or screens and in the game description, 'help' or 'how to play/bet' pages or screens. As a minimum, restricted display devices should provide a link to further information on gambling pages/screens or in 'help', 'about' or 'how to bet/play' pages or screens.
key_points: If operator uses bots/programs to participate, must display easily accessible information
Must clearly inform customers that operator uses this software
Display in game description, help, how to play/bet pages
Restricted display devices: minimum requirement is link to further information
implementation_guidance.when_applicable: Where operators use programs to participate in gambling on their behalf in peer-to-peer gambling

disclosure_requirements.accessibility: Easily accessible information must be displayed
disclosure_requirements.clarity: Must clearly inform customers that operator uses this kind of software

standard_devices: How to play/bet pages or screens

link_locations: How to bet/play pages or screens

examples.poker_robots: Operators using poker robots must disclose this clearly

compliance_notes.overall_purpose: Ensure transparency about use of bots and third party software in peer-to-peer gambling
compliance_notes.enforcement_priority: High - critical for fair peer-to-peer gambling
key_principles: Customer awareness of bots and software-assisted play
Detection and prevention of prohibited software
Operator transparency when using own bots
